textClass.keywords: Metal borohydrides with perovskite structure type: ionic conduction and hydrogen storage

div.p: Many different systems containing perovskite borohydrides AB(BH 4 ) 3 with A = alkali metal, B = rare-earth were studied. Two typical examples are given below:

div.head: LiBH 4 + KBH 4 + YbCl 3
div.p: The perovskite phase KYb(BH 4 ) 3 is formed in ball milled mixtures 12:4:3. At RT the perovskite is simple cubic, and at 95°C it transforms to the orthorhombic phase with 8 × superstructure SQRT(2) / 2 / 2SQRT(2) which was not reported among oxide perovskites [1]:

The decrease of the cell volume above 180°C is due to dissolution of chloride from LiCl in the perovskite. Lanthanides form the basis of RGB (red-green-blue) colours in LED-based solid-state lighting with many important applications. Room temperature emission and excitation spectra of KYb(BH 4 ) 3 were measured in our laboratory down to 10 K. The Yb 2+ emission is centred at 520 nm, when excited in the UV at 355 nm [1]. LiBH 4 + KBH 4 + Gd(BH 4 ) 3 Gadolinium crystals are of interest as host materials for trivalent lanthanides based phosphors. Gadolinium forms double-perovskite phases Cs 3 Gd(BH 4 ) 6 and Cs 2 LiGd(BH 4 ) 6 with bigger alkali metal [1]. A different phase is formed with smaller alkali metal K in the mixtures 4:3:3, but also without lithium in mixtures 0:3:2 as shown on the T-ramp of 4:3:3 mixture in Figure 2. Despite a great effort invested in its crystal structure solution, no satisfactory model has been obtained yet.
[1] Schouwink et al., Nature Comm., submitted.
